title: CalmiGo Review: Can the Device Melt Stress?
description: We review the clinical trials on CalmiGo to give our take on whether the device is likely to relieve stress or if it's a waste of money. We share our concerns about the scents used and feature real, unsponsored CalmiGo customer reviews.

We recommend that patients follow their doctor's guidance in regard to anti-anxiety measures. CalmiGo is a patented stress relief device. The manufacturer claims that it's clinically proven to work, and that it "provides immediate drug-free relief in moments of anxiety, stress and panic attacks." But is CalmiGo based on good science or are these just marketing claims? How does it work in the body? How do real users rate and describe the effects of CalmiGo? And what retailer sells the device for the best price? In this article we'll answer all of these questions and more as we analyze the clinical trials on CalmiGo to give our take on whether the device is likely to be effective or if it's a waste of money. We'll also feature real, unsponsored CalmiGo user reviews and provide a price comparison showing what retailer sells it for the best price. Is CalmiGo Proven to Work? CalmiGo claims that their device has been tested in eight clinical trials, and to the credit of the brand, some of these trials appear to be published in legitimate, peer-reviewed journals which is the gold standard of product research. A [clinical trial](https://link.springer.com/epdf/10.1007/s10484-020-09494-9?sharing_token=avp7NbAoWYTDkFU32NXDz_e4RwlQNchNByi7wbcMAY4l3WhfQERAGOdURq3HXlHQELurrDH2MxORHqLQP1hTtRkOWJ5EppRRaLRNz1AQc46lqnFNWqkorccTsXTJ4PVck9mZrfs31g1cMoyeNEV4lmP3bUwRhPz1bZDplG0fTdg=) published in the Applied Psychophysiology and Biofeedback journal tested the effects of CalmiGo on test anxiety and the device was found to be highly effective. Stress levels decreased by 19% in the CalmiGo group. Another [clinical trial](https://docsend.com/view/s5mmj8k2spnmtvay) found that CalmiGo significantly reduced stress and PTSD levels in combat veterans. However, this study does not appear to be published in any journals so the standard of evidence is weaker than the previous study in our opinion. These are the only clinical trials with published results, and the brand claims that there are six more ongoing clinical trials. Based on the available evidence, we consider CalmiGo likely to be effective for stress reduction, although the value of the device will be more convincing if the majority of the ongoing studies also report positive results. But how does CalmiGo work? We'll review in the next section. How Does CalmiGo Work? CalmiGo claims to work due to three components: personalized breathing recommendation, grounding and calming scents. Personalized breathing seems like an interesting technology, but we're not sure how novel it is because we know from decades of clinical research that consciously slowing down breathing reduces stress levels. The benefit of "personalization" beyond this would have to be proven in future trials. A 2021 [clinical trial](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34227854/) found that a deep breathing program helped anxious participants reduce stress levels by 24%. Grounding is described by CalmiGo as engaging the four senses. This is different from the [grounding](https://illuminatelabs.org/blogs/health/earthing-health-benefits), also described as "earthing," that we reviewed in a previous article that involves making direct contact with the Earth's soil. Sensory stimulation is [clinically shown](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34708453/) to alter mood, but it seems like it would vary significantly based on the stimulus. We do not find this product benefit to be particularly convincing. Calming scents have been used for thousands of years to induce relaxation, and are often referred to as aromatherapy. CalmiGo uses "Scented Plates" but it's unclear to us what specific materials are used to create the scent. Is the lavender "Scented Plate" purely formulated from lavender essential oil, or does it have other ingredients added? Without this information, we cannot ascertain the safety and potentially efficacy of this part of CalmiGo's technology, and we urge the brand to publish more clearly the materials used on the "Our Scents" page of their website. Given that this is a hardware device rather than an ingestible product, its risk of side effects is likely minimal. Neither CalmiGo clinical trial references any side effects or patients having to discontinue use, which suggests that CalmiGo is unlikely to cause side effects. That being said, we consider the risk of side effects to be slightly higher than the brand claims given our concerns about the materials used to create the scents. If there were artificial fragrance ingredients used, for example, they may cause irritation in some individuals. It may be inadvisable to inhale anything with uncertain contents.
